docs.title: PowerShell DevKit
docs.text:
Keep your PowerShell development environments perfectly synchronized across all your machines

Quick Start View on GitHub

docs.title: 🎯 The Problem It Solves
docs.text:
Tired of manually syncing your development environment across multiple machines?

We've all been there - following lengthy OneNote instructions, manually installing tools, copy-pasting configurations, and hoping you didn't miss anything. Every new machine or reinstall meant hours of tedious setup work.

PowerShell DevKit eliminates that pain:

  • ✅ One command to set up your complete environment
  • ✅ Git-based configuration keeps everything in sync
  • ✅ Automatic updates across all your machines
  • ✅ Intelligent recovery when things go wrong
  • ✅ Consistent experience whether you're on your desktop, laptop, or fresh Windows install

Clone once, run Setup.ps1, and you're done. Your perfect PowerShell environment, reproduced identically everywhere.

docs.title: Building Documentation Locally
docs.text: This guide shows you how to build and preview the MkDocs documentation on your local machine.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.7 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)

docs.title: 1. Install Python Dependencies
docs.text:
# Install from requirements file
pip install -r requirements.txt

Or install individually:

pip install mkdocs-material
pip install mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin

docs.title: Preview Locally
docs.text:
Start a local development server with live reload:

mkdocs serve

Then open your browser to: http://127.0.0.1:8000

The site will automatically reload when you save changes to any documentation file.

docs.title: Build Static Site
docs.text:
Generate the static HTML files:

mkdocs build

The generated site will be in the site/ directory.

docs.title: Clean Build
docs.text:
Remove the site/ directory and rebuild:

# Remove site directory
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force site -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Rebuild
mkdocs build

docs.title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
The documentation automatically deploys to GitHub Pages when you push to the master branch (via GitHub Actions).

To manually deploy:

mkdocs gh-deploy

This will: 1. Build the documentation 2. Push it to the gh-pages branch 3. GitHub Pages will serve it at https://tsabo.github.io/PowerShell-DevKit/

docs.title: What is PowerShell DevKit?
docs.text: PowerShell DevKit is an enterprise-grade automation suite that sets up a complete PowerShell development environment with modern tools, themes, and configurations.

docs.title: Do I need to be an administrator?
docs.text: Administrator rights are recommended for the best experience, but most components will install with standard user permissions. Some features may require manual UAC approval.

docs.title: Will this work on PowerShell 5.1?
docs.text: The setup script will automatically install PowerShell 7+ for you if you're running Windows PowerShell 5.1. PowerShell 7+ is required for full functionality.

docs.title: Can I uninstall components later?
docs.text:
Yes! Each component can be uninstalled independently: 

# Uninstall via winget
winget uninstall oh-my-posh
winget uninstall yazi

# Uninstall PowerShell modules
Uninstall-Module PSFzf

docs.title: How long does installation take?
docs.text: Typically 5-10 minutes depending on your internet connection and whether components are already installed.

docs.title: Can I install on multiple machines?
docs.text: Yes! Clone the repository on each machine and run Setup.ps1. The setup is idempotent—it skips already-installed components.

docs.title: What if setup fails partway through?
docs.text: Simply re-run Setup.ps1. Already-installed components will be detected and skipped, and it will continue from where it failed.

docs.title: Can I customize what gets installed?
docs.text: Currently, you can skip optional components during setup.

docs.title: How do I update everything?
docs.text:
.\Scripts\Update.ps1

This updates all winget packages, PowerShell modules, and Yazi components.

docs.title: How do I customize my prompt?
docs.text: Edit the oh-my-posh theme files in Config/oh-my-posh/.

docs.title: How do I add my own PowerShell functions?
docs.text: Create them in PowerShell/CustomModules/ or PowerShell/CustomProfile.ps1.

docs.title: Can I use a different terminal?
docs.text: Yes, but Windows Terminal is recommended. The setup auto-configures Windows Terminal. Other terminals may require manual configuration.

docs.title: How do I launch Yazi?
docs.text:
Simply type yazi in PowerShell: 

yazi

docs.title: Yazi shortcuts aren't working
docs.text:
Make sure you've reloaded your profile: 

. $PROFILE

docs.title: How do I add more Yazi plugins?
docs.text:
# List available plugins
ya pkg list

# Add a plugin
ya pkg add "username/plugin-name"

docs.title: Can I use my own Yazi configuration?
docs.text: Yes! The setup clones the configuration from a git repository. You can: 1. Fork the yazi_config repository 2. Modify Components.psm1 to point to your fork 3. Customize the configuration in your fork

docs.title: Fonts look weird in my prompt
docs.text:
Install the CascadiaCode Nerd Font: 

oh-my-posh font install CascadiaCode

Then set it in Windows Terminal settings.

docs.title: winget commands aren't working
docs.text:
Ensure winget is installed: 

winget --version

If not installed, update Windows or install App Installer from Microsoft Store.

docs.title: Some modules failed to install
docs.text:
Trust the PowerShell Gallery: 

Set-PSRepository -Name PSGallery -InstallationPolicy Trusted

docs.title: Where are the logs?
docs.text: Setup logs are in .\Scripts\Logs\Setup_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS.log.

docs.title: Where is my PowerShell profile?
docs.text:
# View profile location
$PROFILE

# Open profile
code $PROFILE

docs.title: How do I change my oh-my-posh theme?
docs.text:
Edit your profile ($PROFILE) and change the theme path: 

oh-my-posh init pwsh --config "path\to\your\theme.omp.json" | Invoke-Expression

docs.title: Can I sync my configuration across machines?
docs.text: Yes! The entire PowerShell-DevKit folder can be version-controlled. Custom modules and profiles are in separate directories that can be synced.

docs.title: How often should I run Update.ps1?
docs.text: Weekly or monthly is recommended, or whenever you want the latest versions of tools.

docs.title: Will updates break my customizations?
docs.text: No. Custom modules, custom profile, and Yazi local modifications are preserved during updates.

docs.title: Can I auto-update?
docs.text: You can schedule Update.ps1 with Windows Task Scheduler, but it's recommended to review updates manually.

docs.title: Can I contribute?
docs.text: Yes! Check the repository for contribution guidelines.

docs.title: How do I understand the architecture?
docs.text: The system uses a component-based architecture with orchestrator scripts (Setup.ps1, Test.ps1, Update.ps1) and a shared component definition module (Components.psm1).

docs.title: Can I add my own components?
docs.text: Yes! Components are defined in Scripts/Components.psm1 with properties like Name, Source, and custom installers.

docs.title: Is this compatible with WSL?
docs.text: The PowerShell DevKit is designed for Windows PowerShell. For WSL, you'd need to adapt it for Linux package managers and paths.

docs.title: Execution Policy Error
docs.text:
Symptom: 

.\Scripts\Setup.ps1 : File cannot be loaded because running scripts is disabled on this system.

Solution: 

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

  2. Open Settings → Windows Update

docs.title: Component System
docs.text: The PowerShell DevKit uses a centralized component definition system to ensure consistency and maintainability across all scripts.

docs.title: Components.psm1
docs.text:
The heart of the system is Scripts/Components.psm1, which exports a single function:

Get-EnvironmentComponents

This function returns an array of component definitions that Setup.ps1, Test.ps1, and Update.ps1 all consume.

docs.title: Base Structure
docs.text:
@{
    Name = [string]           # Display name
    Type = [string]           # "winget" | "module" | "custom"
    IsOptional = [bool]       # Skip with -SkipOptional flag
    Properties = @{           # Type-specific properties
        # Varies by type
    }
    CustomInstaller = [scriptblock]  # Optional
    CustomValidator = [scriptblock]  # Optional
}

docs.title: Winget Components
docs.text:
For applications installed via Windows Package Manager:

@{
    Name = "Yazi"
    Type = "winget"
    IsOptional = $false
    Properties = @{
        PackageId = "sxyazi.yazi"
    }
}

Properties:

  • PackageId - The winget package identifier

docs.title: Module Components
docs.text:
For PowerShell modules from PSGallery:

@{
    Name = "PSFzf"
    Type = "module"
    IsOptional = $false
    Properties = @{
        ModuleName = "PSFzf"
        MinimumVersion = "2.5.0"  # Optional
    }
}

Properties:

  • ModuleName - The PowerShell Gallery module name
  • MinimumVersion - Optional minimum version requirement

docs.title: Custom Components
docs.text:
For components with custom installation/validation logic:

@{
    Name = "Yazi Configuration"
    Type = "custom"
    IsOptional = $false
    Properties = @{
        ConfigRepo = "https://github.com/Tsabo/yazi_config.git"
        ConfigPath = "$env:APPDATA\yazi"
    }
    CustomInstaller = {
        param($Component)

        $configPath = $Component.Properties.ConfigPath
        if (Test-Path $configPath) {
            # Update existing
            Push-Location $configPath
            git pull
            Pop-Location
            return $true
        } else {
            # Clone new
            git clone $Component.Properties.ConfigRepo $configPath
            return $?
        }
    }
    CustomValidator = {
        param($Component)

        $configPath = $Component.Properties.ConfigPath
        $installed = Test-Path $configPath

        return @{
            IsInstalled = $installed
            Version = if ($installed) { "Git-managed" } else { $null }
        }
    }
}

Properties:

  • Custom properties as needed by the component
  • CustomInstaller - Script block for installation
  • CustomValidator - Script block for validation

docs.title: Discovery
docs.text:
# Scripts import and call the function
Import-Module (Join-Path $PSScriptRoot "Components.psm1") -Force
$components = Get-EnvironmentComponents

docs.title: Filtering
docs.text:
# Setup.ps1 can skip optional components
if ($SkipOptional) {
    $components = $components | Where-Object { -not $_.IsOptional }
}

docs.title: Installation (Setup.ps1)
docs.text:
foreach ($component in $components) {
    switch ($component.Type) {
        "winget" {
            Install-WingetPackage -PackageId $component.Properties.PackageId `
                                  -Name $component.Name
        }
        "module" {
            Install-PowerShellModule -ModuleName $component.Properties.ModuleName `
                                      -Name $component.Name
        }
        "custom" {
            $result = & $component.CustomInstaller $component
            if (-not $result) {
                Write-SetupLog -Component $component.Name -Type "custom" `
                              -ErrorMessage "Custom installer failed"
            }
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Validation (Test.ps1)
docs.text:
foreach ($component in $components) {
    $result = Test-EnvironmentComponent -Component $component

    if ($result.IsInstalled) {
        Write-Installed -Name $component.Name -Version $result.Version
    } else {
        Write-Missing -Name $component.Name
    }
}

docs.title: Updates (Update.ps1)
docs.text:
# Group by type for efficient batch updates
$wingetComponents = $components | Where-Object { $_.Type -eq "winget" }
$moduleComponents = $components | Where-Object { $_.Type -eq "module" }

# Update winget packages
foreach ($component in $wingetComponents) {
    Update-WingetPackage -PackageId $component.Properties.PackageId
}

# Update PowerShell modules
foreach ($component in $moduleComponents) {
    Update-Module -Name $component.Properties.ModuleName -Force
}

# Update custom components
$customComponents = $components | Where-Object { $_.Type -eq "custom" }
foreach ($component in $customComponents) {
    & $component.CustomInstaller $component
}

docs.title: Complex Custom Component
docs.text:
For components requiring custom logic:

@{
    Name = "Custom Integration"
    Type = "custom"
    IsOptional = $false
    Properties = @{
        Url = "https://example.com/download"
        InstallPath = "$env:LOCALAPPDATA\CustomTool"
    }
    CustomInstaller = {
        param($Component)

        try {
            # Download
            $url = $Component.Properties.Url
            $path = $Component.Properties.InstallPath

            Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -OutFile "$path\tool.exe"

            # Verify
            if (Test-Path "$path\tool.exe") {
                return $true
            }
            return $false
        }
        catch {
            Write-Error "Installation failed: $_"
            return $false
        }
    }
    CustomValidator = {
        param($Component)

        $path = $Component.Properties.InstallPath
        $exePath = "$path\tool.exe"

        if (Test-Path $exePath) {
            # Get version if available
            $version = & $exePath --version 2>$null
            return @{
                IsInstalled = $true
                Version = $version
            }
        }

        return @{
            IsInstalled = $false
            Version = $null
        }
    }
}

docs.text: Some components depend on others. This is handled through:

docs.title: Order of Installation
docs.text:
Components are installed in the order defined in Components.psm1. Place dependencies first:

# Git must be installed before posh-git
@{
    Name = "Git"
    Type = "winget"
    Properties = @{ PackageId = "Git.Git" }
}

# posh-git depends on Git
@{
    Name = "posh-git"
    Type = "module"
    Properties = @{ ModuleName = "posh-git" }
}

docs.title: Conditional Installation
docs.text:
Check for dependencies in custom installers:

CustomInstaller = {
    param($Component)

    # Check if prerequisite exists
    if (-not (Get-Command git -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue)) {
        Write-Warning "Git is required but not found"
        return $false
    }

    # Proceed with installation
    # ...
}

docs.title: Component Testing
docs.text:
Test components using Test-EnvironmentComponent:

# Import module
Import-Module .\Scripts\Components.psm1 -Force

# Get components
$components = Get-EnvironmentComponents

# Test a specific component
$yaziComponent = $components | Where-Object { $_.Name -eq "Yazi" }
$result = Test-EnvironmentComponent -Component $yaziComponent

# Check result
if ($result.IsInstalled) {
    Write-Host "Yazi is installed: $($result.Version)"
} else {
    Write-Host "Yazi is not installed"
}

docs.title: Overview

  2. Smart Suggestions - Pattern-matching error analysis

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: PowerShell DevKit is built on an enterprise-grade, component-based architecture designed for maintainability, extensibility, and reliability.

docs.title: 1. Component-Based Design
docs.text:
The system uses a shared component library (Components.psm1) that provides a single source of truth for all component definitions. This ensures consistency across all orchestrator scripts.

Key Benefits:

  • DRY Principle - No duplication between Setup.ps1, Test.ps1, and Update.ps1
  • Maintainability - Single place to modify component definitions
  • Consistency - Same component logic across all scripts
  • Extensibility - Easy to add new components

docs.title: 2. Intelligent Failure Recovery
docs.text:
Advanced logging system with actionable suggestions that helps users diagnose and resolve issues quickly.

Features:

  • JSON-based diagnostics with full context
  • Smart suggestion engine based on error patterns
  • Failure frequency tracking
  • Component-specific troubleshooting

docs.title: 3. Modular Orchestration
docs.text:
Three main orchestrator scripts handle different lifecycle phases:

  • Setup.ps1 - Initial installation and configuration
  • Test.ps1 - Validation and health checking
  • Update.ps1 - Multi-source package updates

docs.title: Setup Process
docs.text:
1. Load Components - Import component definitions from Components.psm1
  2. Filter Components - Apply -SkipOptional if specified
  3. Install Components - Iterate through components and install based on type
  4. Deploy Configuration - Copy configuration files to appropriate locations
  5. Validate Installation - Run validation checks
  6. Log Failures - Record any failures with detailed context

docs.title: Test Process
docs.text:
1. Load Components - Import component definitions
  2. Validate Each - Test installation and configuration
  3. Collect Results - Gather version information and status
  4. Display Report - Show categorized results with summary

docs.title: Update Process
docs.text:
1. Load Components - Import component definitions
  2. Update by Type - Group by package manager
  3. Parallel Updates - Update multiple sources concurrently
  4. Validate Updates - Verify updates completed successfully
  5. Log Failures - Record any failures

docs.title: 1. Create Module File

# Create new module

# Or copy template

          "PowerShell\CustomModules\MyTools.psm1"

docs.title: 2. Define Functions
docs.text:
# PowerShell/CustomModules/MyTools.psm1

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    My custom PowerShell utilities
.DESCRIPTION
    Collection of helper functions for my workflow
#>

function Get-ProjectStatus {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Get status of all projects
    .DESCRIPTION
        Scans dev directory for git repositories and shows their status
    .EXAMPLE
        Get-ProjectStatus
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param(
        [string]$Path = "C:\Dev"
    )

    Get-ChildItem -Path $Path -Directory | ForEach-Object {
        if (Test-Path (Join-Path $_.FullName ".git")) {
            Write-Host "$($_.Name):" -ForegroundColor Cyan
            Push-Location $_.FullName
            git status -s
            Pop-Location
            Write-Host ""
        }
    }
}

function Start-DevEnvironment {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Start development environment
    .DESCRIPTION
        Opens common tools and navigates to project directory
    .EXAMPLE
        Start-DevEnvironment -Project "MyApp"
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param(
        [Parameter(Mandatory)]
        [string]$Project
    )

    $projectPath = "C:\Dev\$Project"

    if (Test-Path $projectPath) {
        Set-Location $projectPath
        code .
        Write-Host "Development environment started for $Project" -ForegroundColor Green
    } else {
        Write-Error "Project not found: $projectPath"
    }
}

# Export functions
Export-ModuleMember -Function Get-ProjectStatus, Start-DevEnvironment

#>

$script:ModuleConfig = @{
    DefaultPath = "C:\Data"
    Timeout = 30
}

# Functions

}

    [CmdletBinding()]

    if ($Timeout) { $script:ModuleConfig.Timeout = $Timeout }

    # Operation code
}

docs.title: 1. Comment-Based Help
docs.text:
Always include help for your functions:

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Brief description
.DESCRIPTION
    Detailed description
.PARAMETER Name
    Parameter description
.EXAMPLE
    Example-Function -Name "Test"
    Description of what this example does
.NOTES
    Additional information
#>

docs.title: 2. Parameter Validation
docs.text:
Use parameter attributes:

function Get-Data {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param(
        [Parameter(Mandatory)]
        [ValidateNotNullOrEmpty()]
        [string]$Source,

        [ValidateRange(1, 100)]
        [int]$Count = 10,

        [ValidateSet("Fast", "Normal", "Slow")]
        [string]$Speed = "Normal"
    )
}

docs.title: 3. Error Handling
docs.text:
Use try/catch and appropriate error actions:

function Get-SafeData {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param([string]$Path)

    try {
        if (-not (Test-Path $Path)) {
            throw "Path not found: $Path"
        }

        $data = Get-Content $Path -ErrorAction Stop
        return $data
    }
    catch {
        Write-Error "Failed to get data: $_"
        return $null
    }
}

docs.title: 4. Write Output
docs.text:
Use Write-Verbose, Write-Debug, etc.:

function Process-Data {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param([string]$Data)

    Write-Verbose "Processing data..."
    Write-Debug "Data length: $($Data.Length)"

    # Processing...

    Write-Verbose "Processing complete"
}

# PowerShell/CustomModules/DevWorkflow.psm1

    [CmdletBinding()]

    # Navigate to project

    # Open VS Code
    code .

    # Start Docker if needed
    if (Test-Path "docker-compose.yml") {
        Write-Host "Starting Docker containers..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
        docker-compose up -d
    }

    # Open browser
    Start-Process "http://localhost:3000"

    Write-Host "Work session started for $Project" -ForegroundColor Green
}

function Stop-WorkSession {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param()

    # Stop Docker
    if (Test-Path "docker-compose.yml") {
        Write-Host "Stopping Docker containers..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
        docker-compose down
    }

    Write-Host "Work session ended" -ForegroundColor Green
}

# ============================================================================
# FUNCTIONS
# ============================================================================

function Start-DevDay {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Starts my development day
    #>
    Set-Location $env:DEV_ROOT
    code .
    Start-Process chrome
    Write-Host "Development day started!" -ForegroundColor Green
}

function Get-DevStatus {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Shows status of all dev projects
    #>
    Get-ChildItem $env:DEV_ROOT -Directory | ForEach-Object {
        if (Test-Path (Join-Path $_.FullName ".git")) {
            Write-Host "`n$($_.Name):" -ForegroundColor Cyan
            Push-Location $_.FullName
            git status -s
            Pop-Location
        }
    }
}

function Update-AllProjects {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Updates all git repositories in dev folder
    #>
    Get-ChildItem $env:DEV_ROOT -Directory | ForEach-Object {
        if (Test-Path (Join-Path $_.FullName ".git")) {
            Write-Host "Updating $($_.Name)..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
            Push-Location $_.FullName
            git pull
            Pop-Location
        }
    }
}

# ============================================================================
# ADDITIONAL MODULES
# ============================================================================

# Company-specific tools
if (Get-Module -ListAvailable CompanyTools) {
    Import-Module CompanyTools
}

# ============================================================================
# PSREADLINE CUSTOMIZATION
# ============================================================================

Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler -Key Ctrl+d -Function DeleteChar
Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler -Key Alt+d -Function DeleteWord

# ============================================================================
# STARTUP ACTIONS
# ============================================================================

# Show reminder
Write-Host "CustomProfile loaded. Type " -NoNewline
Write-Host "Start-DevDay" -ForegroundColor Cyan -NoNewline
Write-Host " to begin working."

docs.title: Setup.ps1
docs.text: The Setup.ps1 script is the primary installation tool that automates the complete setup of your PowerShell development environment.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Purpose: Install and configure all components of the PowerShell DevKit

Features:

  • ✅ Component-based installation
  • ✅ Intelligent failure recovery
  • ✅ Timeout protection
  • ✅ Detailed logging
  • ✅ Skip already-installed components
  • ✅ Optional component filtering

docs.title: Standard Installation
docs.text:
# Full installation (recommended)
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

This will:

  1. Check prerequisites (PowerShell 7+, winget)
  2. Install core tools via winget
  3. Install PowerShell modules
  4. Deploy configuration files
  5. Set up Yazi ecosystem
  6. Install optional components
  7. Validate installation

docs.title: As Administrator
docs.text:
# Run PowerShell as Administrator, then:
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

Benefits:

  • All components install successfully
  • No UAC prompts during installation
  • Font installation works correctly

docs.title: Idempotent Behavior
docs.text:
Setup.ps1 is idempotent - safe to run multiple times:

  • Already-installed components are detected and skipped
  • Configuration files are updated if changed
  • Failed components can be retried

Example:

🔹 Installing Yazi...
  → Checking if already installed...
  ⊘ Yazi is already installed

docs.title: Timeout Protection
docs.text:
All operations have timeouts to prevent hangs:

Operation Timeout Package check 15 seconds Package installation 60 seconds Git clone 30 seconds

When timeout occurs:

  → Check timed out, proceeding with installation...

Or:

  ⚠ Installation timed out, skipping component
